Stay off any addictions or do NOT add to them (I self medicated with alcohol for a while which got me through but extremely unhealthy) and then faced weening myself off that too! I found help groups on FB where also very informative and was pleased to find verification of some behaviour as well as being able to vent without prejudice… NO CONTACT is the best for your mental health - Stay strong and try to be positive - the road to recovery and getting over grief is not easy - although I am assured it is worth it!

It's a process that will occur over a period of time, in steps. Learning as much about Narcissistic abuse and how it affects you can streamline the process. No good will come from blaming the narcissist, the only way to grow and heal through this process is to accept responsibility for allowing the abuse to continue. You cannot fix things outside you, but you can change you. It really helps to have people to talk that also have been through it. People who have not been thru it do not get the hell you have been thru and will not understand it. The advise they give will be watered down accordingly. Love yourself, you have to learn to do that. Good luck.

A big part for me is understanding why it happened. The funny part of that is that I had therapy 20 years ago during a horrible divorce. I learned to set borders, respect myself and make others respect me. Never anything about narcissism. Due to (my new) family circumstances I am for the last 3 years in full swing with codependency and narcissism. I learned a lot more, can give an explanation even including why both my present partner and I are/have been codependent. That gave me a big boost in making my foundation a lot stronger. I understand I am not a victim , but did not have the knowledge to counter it. Now I have and its very reassuring it will simply not happen again

Move away!!! Take yourself out on dates and find out who you are, what you like, spend time alone, as well as meet new people! Widen your support system. Find ways to make each holiday special by planning in advance. Take a class in something that inspires you! It’s time to get out there and recreate your life. in the process, Maybe join a support group if there is an issue that has bothered you that needs to be addressed. Take the time to join a circle of recovery! Take all the time you need for learning to love yourself! It’s about redefining yourself as someone who survived some awful stuff! But you were under a spell! Now let yourself love you!

With help. Obviously I don’t know the details of the abuse but abuse from being in a narcissistic relationship is often bad enough to cause PTSD. In Australia, a trip to the GP and you can access a mental health plan, which will give you up to 12 counselling sessions for free. Ask around to find a therapist that is skilful with recovery after a brush with narcissism, not all are. Be super kind to your self and learn learn learn. Look up Richard Grannon on the internet … a very skilled psychologist who had experienced living with a narcissist and will give you the skills and knowledge to pull yourself out of the hole you are in. And most importantly, do everything you can to develop a healthy sense of self so that you are not attracted into another abusive relationship again. Hope it eases soon (PS … be determined and follow my advice and it will, believe me).

Focus inward, on you. The goodness that is you will be reflected in the world around you. Allow the pain; it works itself out leaving you much, much wiser and stronger. (If things get a little wonky, reach out for help, NEVER the narc or their friends or family - the narc already has them well-trained to suck out your life blood).

Learn about narcissism in order to protect yourself from any narcissists you may encounter in the future. Practice self care: drink plenty of water, exercise like you should, get enough rest. Indulge yourself: avail yourself of all the goodies you had to pass up due to the narcissist’s vile presence. Make an effort to surround yourself with people who lift your spirits or otherwise nurture you (as opposed to drain you) in some way. Remove anything that reminds you of the narcissist - ANYTHING. These are things that helped me.

It helps me to talk to other people who have experienced living with a narcissist or being around a narcissist. It validates you and makes you feel like you're not alone and you can get through it. I see a psychiatrist and a therapist simply because I had an extremely abusive childhood and 2 abusive marriages due to being brought up by 2 extreme narcissists. Believe me it can cause a lot of trauma and damage and it is very helpful to get a professional opinion on how you are dealing with it. I find this website extremely helpful.

I may not be the best placed to answer this question having been broken by narc twisted love too. But my take would be crawl out the pain,don't stop feeling what you feel. However long it takes ….just feel the confusion, dont forget your part,it could have been you were the constant supply.Do point out the red flags you ignored,go all out and cry.meanwhile ,make all effort to rebuild,your health,your relations,your finances.If the narc left you in ashes like my case,you got a lot to rebuild.Start with your health which is most vital because your revenge is to live your life to the best of your capability.Period.

Great job! First, be proud of yourself. You are smart, strong and brave. I HIGHLY recommend EFT tapping to recover from the abuse and whatever set you up for it in the first place. You likely have to do some deep, inner-child work. It can be a bit rough at first but it will get easier, and you will feel sooooo much better. In time, you will have reset your patterns and will no longer attract or be attracted to abusers. Congratulations! Hang in there!

Here’s about two years worth of work for you (and absolutely worth it!) How to recognize and recover from sociopaths, psychopaths, narcissists and other exploiters Love Fraud . com and Sam Vaknin That will keep you busy AND will help you past the pain and into a much happier life. Get going!

For me, the key to thriving after Narcissistic Abuse is: Showing myself mercy when I stumble or fall down completely.Allowing myself to feel the sudden shocks of pain that sometimes overwhelm me with no explanation.Keeping a positive, yet realistic attitude.Laughing as often as possible, however possible.Being humble enough to make a complete fool out of myself, and laugh about it.

Self care and getting reassurance from those around you as much is possible. Just realizing that you are okay without the narcissist and you do not depend on him for your self-worth. Remember, do not give in to the narcissist if they try to contact you. Stay out of the relationship.
Meeting others going through the same thing and talking to them, read, YouTube, therapy, LOTS OF TEARS, try not to isolate, self-educate, remember: YOU'RE A GOOD PERSON, THAT'S WHY YOU WERE TARGETED!

By renewing YOUR mind with positive thoughts on a daily basis. Think goods things, happy thoughts. Cast out the ugliness of this world. Go visit someone in need, share your true, loving empathic self with someone deserving. Breathe, pray, eat well, rest.…rinse and repeat.

I found it helpful to study NPD. I’ve read books and watched presentations by psychologists on you tube. Quora has been very good also, by reading about others’ experiences I’ve learned a lot. By studying this subject and finding out the truth about the emotionless snake behind the mask it’s made it easier to stay away. It’s helped me with my resolve to end it forever.

STAY no contact! No matter how hard it is. No matter what happens, no matter how you really feel, no matter What! STAY NO CONTACT. Once you get out of their orbit, you will begin to see more each day that it is NOT what you want. Stay No Contact!

I found much resonance and help with free YouTube videos from Lisa A Romano, Melanie Tonia Evans and Richard Grannon. Also the site About Flying Monkeys Denied has great information. It takes time and patience to regain your mental health again after this type of abuse. Be patient and kind with yourself. ❤️
It's hard. Stay busy. Get support. Whatever you do do not have contact with that narc. Dont do it. You'll be forever sorry if you do.
Study this to understand the “game” into which you were drawn. https://www.lynneforrest.com/articles/2008/06/the-faces-of-victim/
Go onto Tink Amyra YouTube thereyou will find a video on coping strategies..
